A few who survived the massacre, with the widows and children of the slain, joined the neighbour- ing AbiponeS, and both nations, by inter—mar- riages, coalesced into one; the old language of the Yaaucanigas falling into disuse. The Abi- ponian tribes pursue the same manner of life, and their customs and language, with the ex- ception of a few words, are alike. Wondrous unanimity, and a constant alliance in arms, reigned amongst them as long as they had to deal with the Spaniards, against whom, as against a mutual foe, they bear an innate hatred, and whose servitude they resist with united strength. But though bound by the ties of consanguinity and friendship‚'impatient of the smallest injury, they eagerly seize on any occa-X sion of war, and frequently weaken each other with mutual slaughter.
